reviews.review_text: I just finished Austin Jorgenson's LISA and can say that, without a doubt, it is among the strongest indie RPGs I have ever played. I was hooked on the world of LISA with the slight taste given by the prequel, LISA: The First, which had me eagerly awaiting this title. The developer cites Mother as a key influence and that shows, but even more than the abstract game OFF, LISA has taken the wacky humor and surreal style of Mother into a dark and very adult place. Dingaling is able to take simple, old school pixels and work them into truly disturbing imagery. Lately, we have been inundated with post-apocalyptic settings that are xeroxed and re-sampled at will: zombies, plague, fallout and bad weather. All of those settings, done to death, are fairly grim, but none of them can even touch the misery suggested by LISA. Here we have a world where women are extinct and the surviving men, seeing no future for humanity, have transformed the society into a sort of prison yard where hopelessness is drowned in drugs and alcohol, and memories seem uniformly sad. The main protagonist, Brad, is driven by a past filled with abuse and grief, and literally sets himself against the will of the entire world. The player will be forced to make tough decisions in this game and to eventually think about and judge the outcome. Even as we laugh at sight gags and endless pro wrestling references, one cannot ignore the uneasy slithering quality of LISA. My greatest hope is that the game does well and Dingaling games develops more titles where the heart of the game is a great story, not the ability to snipe someone in multiplayer. Bravo!

With all the hype for Undertale, it's a shame that this game passed under the radar last year for many people.  LISA is an RPG that'll make you hate life. No, not by its difficulty, as its pretty basic as far as RPGs go, but by how cruel and sadistic the world it presents to you is. It feels strange how this obscure indie game creates a more believable and interesting post-apocolyptic world than Fallout ever did. It's genuiley threatening and disturbing, despite its silly Earthbound-esque vibe. I never thought an RPG maker game could give me an actual sense of dread.  Tons of party members, satisfying combat, tons of abilities with their own unique animations, funny moments, scary moments, sad moments, and a story that'll leave you satisfied and empty at the same time.  This game is actually the sequel to another game, known as LISA: the First. A Yume-Nikki style game that contains fun topics such as child ♥♥♥♥ and abuse. It's not necessary to play that game to fully understand the story, but it's still worth a look. Be warned, both these games can be pretty graphic.

Note: Do not play 'Lisa: The Joyful' first. It's intended as the finale to this game 'Lisa: The Painful' I haven't played Joyful at the time of this writing. TLDR This game is worth playing if you're tired of bad storytelling in video games and want something eccentric and unique unto itself.  It's hard to write about the game without spoiling some of it, but I won't name critical points. It's a RPG with a 4 slot party system, EXP, levels, and mixing and matching party members as you discover them throughout an apocalyptic world populated entirely by men and all that entails. It's a very *human* world, twisted through a bizarre tone that expresses itself through experimental and sometimes grossly unnerving music, the art, and the mechanics especially.  Great care's taken in making every single party member have their own theme and flavor. Even mechanics tied to resting in the wilderness speak to the game's theme of pain and hostility. To say this game is quirky and bizarre is an understatement though. I felt a constant sense of tension and unease as I played, but I think that was largely the point.  Plenty of humor kept it from beating me over the head with constant reminders that the world's screwed, and my main character's drug addiction getting in the way and tempting me to feed his demons. There is a drug called Joy that gives party members, and your permanent player-character, massive bonuses and chases off the heavily penalizing withdrawal status effects.  I'd highly recommend this game to anybody who loves quirky humor and darker, adult themes. It truly was a horror, and there are very few heroics to speak of except for the silly boys that made up their own rules in a traumatized wasteland that's both horrific and playful.   It's our Earth alright?  I could go over every little detail on why this game is more human than the trite Good vs Evil nonsense that typically plays out in other stories, but the sweaty wonderland is best experienced with an open mind.   ---   Other boring notes:  Didn't 100% the game, don't plan on doing a Pain-Difficulty run.  Did read spoilers post-ending.  Took about 15 hours blind on Normal difficulty, missed several areas in that time.  Some of them are very well-hidden, so if you like mystery and exploring the overworld based on NPC hints, you'll probably feel pretty clever for your experimenting!

I have played and beat the pre-release of LISA two times and now again for the third time on steam. I will try to collect my thoughts, that gathered up during that time with the game, into this review. I will try to avoid spoilers.  LISA without a doubt is a  very special game . It is one man's passion project. (scroll to the end for TL:DR version)   THE PRICE:  Special games such as this are rarely made to completion, and when they are, their nature is such that it demands concessions.  This is a technically weak game for what people might expect from a commercial title, options are scarce, controller setup highly counter intuitive, resolution non-adjustable, and full-screen mode hard set. It has all the issues you might expect from a game made on a RPG-maker platform, such as an antiquated battle system and very rigid platforming.  If technical shortcomings of a game turn you off, I would like to suggest that they shouldn't, as a game is not a car or a tool judged upon its specs primarily, however if you are not willing to make some concessions to a game over its technical aspect LISA is not for you.   THE VISION:   'The state of nature is such where there is <...> no account of time, no arts, no letters, no society, and which is worst of all, continual fear and danger of violent death, and the life of man, solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short.'  -Thomas Hobbes  Such is the view of life we find in LISA, it is cheap, plentiful, yet brief and ends ignobly in violence. The game mechanics work in concert with the narrative splendidly here, by offering plenty of wonderfully varied and interesting companions to recruit, all with a distinct look and behavior, you could even swear each has a deep and sorrow filled backstory even when they don't, it is all to easy to get attached to these men before they die permanently.  People almost act like a secondary currency, you soon find out that your allies are just another resource that you expend to get where you need to go, but thankfully they never feel like that, making each death at least somewhat painful.  While gameplay and narrative work together great, LISA's  story is its greatest asset   hands down. What at first seems like a regular 'save the damsel' story, is actually so much more. Some minor spoilers coming:  The only girl character- 'Buddy' is a messiah character, she is the only known female, and is seen as someone who can 'save' the world. However, you (as Brad) want to save HER from the world she is meant to save.   The game asks, what is the dignity of a child? Should a world that can produce nothing but misery be allowed to perpetuate at the price of yet another innocence? The answers that emerge through gameplay are often truly shocking and makes decision making very hard. These themes of tragedy are suggested to be rooted at the core of all characters you meet, through encounters like with Horace and understanding the backstory of Rando. The villains and allies you have are often more like you than is often comfortable and everyone partakes in a brotherhood of misery.  As you play you may choose to go with this world's depravity or constantly struggle against it, with more or less success, while becoming more enmeshed into this world as it builds on you, thematically and narratively, with its punishing gameplay. It culminates in one of those rare satisfying endings, which was the only video game ending to truly make me cry.  I can not commend and recommend this game enough. Also the game has a gorgeous soundtrack, and tons of secrets, even whole large areas/towns that you wouldn't otherwise find casually playing the game.   TL:DR : The fact of this games existence is worth celebrating and forgiving the inevitable vices it had to possess to ever be made. This game is excellent not for polish, but for its grand, bleak vision and meaningful story, that together make for a truly painful game. [Pain/10]  Advice: I suggest not abusing the 'reload feature' if someone dies, or you make a choice live with it, what is the point otherwise?

Hotline Miami posed a very important question, one that I believe resonates with this game. Richard's inquiries to Jacket seem to echo throughout this game, and I caught myself wondering about Richard's questions more and more as the game progressed...  LISA is a game about hurt. You play as Brad, a middle-aged nobody residing in the wastes of a ruined world. Brad lives with his lifelong friends in the middle of nowhere. Olathe, the name given to Brad's homeland before everything was destroyed, is sparse with human life, rife with monsters, and is entirely devoid of women. All except for Buddy.  'Where are we right now?'  LISA is a game about hurt. People will hurt Brad. People will hurt each other. Brad will hurt people. Brad will hurt. It's not uncommon to hurt, especially when it's the end of the world. Although, even in the end of the world people don't like to hurt. Maybe you'll take Joy and forget about all the pain and hurt, because Joy helps you forget - at least temporarily. Plus, when you can forget about everything that makes you so pathetic, then you can truly become strong. Besides, you're not the only one using Joy, and Joy has virtually no side effects - save for withdrawal.  'Why are we having this conversation?'  LISA is a game about hurt. The game begs the question of whether or not a few strong men can save the world from a sea of dip♥♥♥♥♥. Are you a strong man? Will you do the right thing?  LISA is a game about hurt, so you need to ask yourself something...    'Do you like hurting other people?'

• Developer: Dingaling • Publisher: Dingaling Productions, LLC • Genre: Adventure/RPG • Release date: Dec 15, 2014 • Played on: PC • Price: $9.99 • Play time: 11 hours  **Spoiler Alert*** This game is demented!  The man sees some kids playing with fire and asks me if I can grab a bucket of water and put out that fire. I oblige by grabbing the nearest bucket and tossing the liquid on the kids, setting them aflame. The startled man quickly informs me that I just used his bucket of gasoline, the water one is further up the hill. Panicked, I climb the hill and grab the bucket of water only to return moments later to piles of ashes where the children once were.  They say the road to Hell is paved with good intentions and that would be a fitting tagline for this game. Lisa is a 2D side scrolling RPG set in a post-apocalyptic world full of weird characters and some of the most disgusting degenerates all wrapped up in a charismatically drawn world. Players take control of Brad, a Joy addicted empty husk of a man seeking redemption by raising and safeguarding one of the world’s few remaining females.   Lisa begins with a series of flashbacks to show Brad’s life and how he became the man he is at the start of the game. Bullied as a kid, an abusive father, drug addiction…but all that seemed to have changed when he came across an abandoned infant one day. He brings the child home to his flat to show his friends and they’re all surprised to find out that the child is a female. Brad then enlists his friends to help take care in raising this girl. They build a basement for her, cover her face in a mask to disguise the fact that she’s a female and Brad even comes to grips in taming his Joy habit for the benefit of his new daughter. However, things don’t always go well in this world and Buddy is kidnapped, most of brad’s friends are murdered which sends Brad on a hunt to rescue his daughter. Occasional hilariousness and often a metric ton of depravity ensues.  I found the game full of dark humor and even some touching moments but there are also some deranged portions so some people might be put off by some of the situations that occur. Lisa is pretty much the opposite of last year’s Undertale in overall tone even though this game does have a few life lessons to be learned.  Traveling around the world takes place in 2D; people are met, ladders are climbed and caves are explored all using adequate graphics. The artstyle isn’t impressive but it is creative with a style of its own. There are roughly 30 companions ranging from clumsy wrestlers, to a two-legged fish that is a lawyer. There’s not Obsidian level depth in these characters but each one has a personality of their own which is seen through the level up screens and the initial dialogue. The biggest example of all the differences between the characters come from their abilities in combat. There’s a slew of different weapons, attacks, buffs and debuffs to choose from and it’s almost a challenge to find out which characters deserve a space in the party.  It’s sort of good that the characters aren’t too memorable or that there are so many of them that their abilities are pretty interchangeable because they can be taken and even perma-killed occasionally. There are a couple bosses that have instant death attacks, resting can get one of your party members ransomed for a fee and other unfortunate endings can await the player character’s companions if the player so chooses. Of course, this sort of misfortune often befalls the PC also and the player will be called upon to decide if a companion is worth one of Brad’s limbs. Choosing to disfigure Brad will usually rescue a companion but will limit Brad’s effectiveness in combat by reducing the number of combos he can do.  Combat is turn-based and the various RPG stats determine the order of turns, amount of damage done and accuracy while equipment boosts attack, defense and resistances. It’s all standard fare. The characters’ attacks however, is where the variety comes in with Brad and a few other characters using a button combinations for attacks while others use words to debuff the enemies and others use special abilities with their weapons to be useful. As I mentioned before, it takes a while to swap out characters and test out their abilities but it’s fun to give each character a test run and see what they are capable of.   The game is pretty good when it comes to choice and consequences besides the limb vs companion choices I previously mentioned. I had some somewhat friendly guys approach me and offer to buy some Molotov cocktails from me only to find that they used them in a most heinous way. This prevented me from meeting certain characters and removing what could have been a bunch of side quests from the game.  Another thing I found satisfying is the world’s economy in the game. Porno mags have turned into a form of currency and it’s something that, while found in abundance, isn’t always easy to keep with the party members being ransomed, new characters sometimes taking a large amount to hire them and new equipment being so expensive. There are certain areas in the game that random encounters occur and I could grind my way towards more cash but I gave up my grinding days years ago.  In the end, this game just stuck in my head a lot longer than most RPGs due to the story and the way the world’s situations were handled. Lisa left me wondering if all my decisions were worth it in the end. I still have yet to play through the DLC just because the end of this game has really stuck with me. Lisa does a good job of separating itself from other RPGs but the dark nature might not be right for everyone.

LISA is a post-apocalyptic 2D-Sidescrolling RPG (doesn't sound amazing, admittedly) with a really surreal, weird atmoshpere and art-style. I picked up this game for 5 bucks on sale and after finishing it, i think it would have well been worth 20 euros. While the game is less gameplay focused and more of a story-teller it still has some solid turn based (pokemon style) combat. And with that basic design you may soon find yourself beating a really hard boss after 13 tortorous attempts to then just accidentally press [->] once too often and walking down a cliff into your death. I couldn't help but be reminded a lot of Earthbound (which is also like pokemon is some ways) only that every now and then something REALLY ♥♥♥♥ed up happens. As far as the story goes, we find ourselves in a really surreal unforgiving world where anything that could be labeled as '♥♥♥♥ED UP' might happen. The aforementioned gameplay is solid, somewhat balanced and easy to understand. Another thing to mention is the soundtrack, as this game has an amazing soundtrack (might not be everyone's thing though) with really funky beats and tortured parts. (I recommend you buy this with the Soundtrack if you're into alternative weird music)  Now let's get to the real part:  PROS: -Gripping Storytelling -Solid Gameplay -Nice Characters -Amazing (altough, weird) Soundtrack -Humorous -Really Unforgiving -Unbelievable Detail in Storytelling  CONS: -Writing and Design are a bit wonky at places (nothing major though) -Has there ever been an intuitive Inventory-Screen? -Really Unforgving   If your heart can take a beating every now and then, accompanied by a solid all-round gaming experience, I definitely recommend this game for this laughable price.

A humorous yet depressing post apocalyptic RPG about surviving a world completely void of woman, filled with perverts and weirdo's, this a sequel to the very lesser known RPG Maker game, 'Lisa The First.' You take control of Brad Armstrong who stumbles upon a female baby named 'Buddy', who is the last hope for this humanity. Being the last female on Olathe, Brad wants to protect her from harm's way. As she grows older, her curious mind lets loose after years of being sheltered, and she inevitably gets captured. Brad set's out to save his adopted daughter, while the Painful journey begins.  Living up to it's name, Lisa 'The Painful', is a game all about sacrifice. Being an Earthbound inspired RPG, the humorous tone is very apparent. Lisa crosses boundaries that not many other games have crossed, some moments you'll laugh, but some you'll be gravely upset with. There are a lot of instances where you don't know what to think, along with sometimes being outright disturbed. I believe this is one thing I really enjoyed about Lisa, it really crossed those boundaries that too many games shy away from these days. It's important to note the sacrifice in this game that I mentioned earlier, you'll have the choice of sacrificing limbs, killing off party members, or maybe ditching all your items. These can end up being legitimately difficult decisions that will affect the gameplay no matter what choice you choose.  What seperates Lisa from other RPG Maker games, is that it's set on a 2D plane. You'll eventually obtain a bicycle which will make for faster transportation. You could call it 'Metroidvania' in the sense where you'll have to backtrack to some areas with your newely accquired items, though it's a lot less complicated, with each crossroad consisting of 4-6 areas you'll be able to visit, making it easier to backtrack to areas without it being a hassle. It's also important to note how Lisa always gives you this feeling of being unsafe. Sleeping at campfires overnight can cause negative effects the next day, such as being poisoned. With over 30 recruitable party members comes with a price, some can leave you over night while resting, and some can end up getting captured. The battle system is your typical RPG stuff, although with few neat things added in. For one, Brad can string together combo's while bursting a special move (that drains MP), to finish it off. Secondly, your 'TP' meter, which raises the more you get hit or deal damage. This allows you to perform some deadly special moves. Last thing that shoud be noted here is that unlike most RPG's, Lisa REALLY encourages exploration rather than grinding for you to level up which I think is a really good approach.  Lisa's soundtrack really is... something else. I can't go too in-depth on it, without saying it's really undescribeable, yet still really awesome and very worth checking out.  Of course there are a couple negative points that should be addressed. Being able to save and load constantly can sometimes draw away from 'The Painful' feeling of the game. If the game forced you to save after sleeping overnight, or making a crucial sacrifice, this definitely would have lived up to it's name a little more. I'm aware the 'pain' difficulty allows you to only save once at every save point, but it doesn't change the fact you can still load to prevent some of these. Sometimes text boxes can't even fit the whole text, it's not a huge deal, but it's really strange when I see a bit of text cut off.  I'm aware I've left out few important details such as 'joy', and who exactly 'Lisa' is. But I can't recommend this enough to anyone whose a fan of 'comedic' RPG's. Be wary though, Lisa make's damn well sure to poke fun at you for some decisions and not hold back on making you feel like ♥♥♥♥ all while being really unsettling. It's important to note, Lisa eventually got a DLC sequel titled 'Lisa The Joyful'. While it lacks the charm of 'The Painful', it's still very worth buying in the complete package. Any RPG fan who wants to see an interesting approach on the genre should definitely pick this up, especially while the complete package is still on sale.

Gameplay 9/10 Music 10/10 Story 10/10 Cons (There really are none) -Be ready for some intense fights and emotional story ----------------------------------------------------------------------- LISA is a unique RPG game where you play as a man with some unique and intersting party members in search for your daughter. I quickly picked up this game towards the ending moments of the Steam Winter Sale and tossed this game into my cart along with my other games. I instantly stopped playing all the other games I bought and focused all of my time into this one RPG game. The gameplay in LISA is difficult and will require you to try over and over again before you manage to defeat your foe, but the people you end up battling can range from disgusting monsters to more personal story characters that you will end up just caring. LISA is a terrible game. LISA, The Painful RPG, goes to many places many RPGs don't dare to go, for better or for worse. LISA can and most likely will punch your face in, only to step on your heart while you are down and make you laugh about it.  Because of that, it's probably one of the best games I've played in quite a while. Warning, TL;DR up ahead.  LISA, The Painful RPG, is an RPGMaker game set in the land of Olathe, Somewhere, USA. You take the pivotal role of Brad Armstrong, a balding drug addict hooked on Booze and Joy to take away the pain of a horrendous family life and god knows how many other regrets. Your sole goal is to find who is possible the last woman on the planet, a girl named Buddy who you helped raised from a baby. On your way, you'll face the worst humanity has to offer, and a few more other monstrosities along the way.  The actual RPG mechanics of the game, for an RPGMaker game, are solid, if not a bit unbalanced. Most of the stats are what they say on the tin, but some of the status ailments, if you forget what they do, offer no hints to what they actually accomplish. The combination of Fire and Oil is also hilariously OP, but in a world as fatal as LISA, is it that OP if it helps you keep people alive? Who could beat some of the more powerful bosses without Birdie around to spit oil and RT or Mad Dog to roast the competition? The combat itself is fairly gratifying, but out of all of the things LISA does, it might be the one thing it doesn't do perfectly. Almost as if there is stuff missing, like rock and paper missing scissors.  What isn't missing, however, is the on point music and sound design. The game can be fairly loud at times, but it is all in the grand scheme with the quirky and appropriate musical compositions W2D put together. It's honestly, in my opinion, one of the things LISA doesn't get enough credit for. The music sets a wonderful tone that follows your story superbly well, and even better when the music is yanked away. There is nothing more eerie than completing your goal, and being greated by a haunting tone of nothing but your footsteps. This design really does accentuate the real positive of LISA; the brilliant story.  LISA's story is a story that I can't help but appreciate. The main character, Bard Armstrong, proves to be such a character deserving of such empathy, but as the story goes along, both he and you are tested in how much you can take. People will die. Sometimes it's the people that you care the most about. Death, doubt, and betrayal are all around you, biting at your heels the moment you think you are in the clear, and there is never a moment where you are safe from the cruelty of post apocolyptic Olathe. The joking, dirty crust of LISA only lures you into the rotten, depressing core that will make you question what you do, and make you ponder the answers of questions you hope to never want to answer in the real world. It'll make you regret. It'll make you doubt. It'll make you hurt.  Even if you are squeamish, or not into RPGs, or any other excuse you could think of, reasonable or otherwise, I  implore  you to take the risk and try LISA. It's a nasty, perverted, and disturbing game, but it is one of the best, if not  THE  best RPG I've ever played. When LISA The Joyful comes out, buy that too. ♥♥♥♥, play LISA the First too. Absorb all the LISA you can get. Embrace it. Taste it. Digest it all. You won't regret it.

I'm gonna go ahead and just quickly address all the mentions (for good or for ill intentions) of Undertale here with an 'Honestly? Stop that'. Comparing the two games unfair to either, as both have their own unique identity. We get it, you really hate or really love Undertale. Now shut your facehole and let people enjoy other things without dragging your stink into it. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.   Anyway...   This game does a LOT of things right, which makes it one of my absolute favorites. In terms of gameplay it manages to stick things as familiar as turn-based combat and moral choice system while still managing to keep things fresh. Things like the combo system for characters like the protagonist and a few recruitable party members, along with the chance of an enemy having an ability to permanently kill any of aforementioned crew, keep your attention without the 'spam the A button to make everyone attack until thing dies' that many RPGs today suffer from. It's simple, but it's also unique.  And on the topic of the moral choice system, can I just point out that anybody writing a post-apocalyptic setting should take some notes from this game's writing? Because LISA does a damn good job of blurring the lines of morality, as a world where everything has gone to ♥♥♥♥ and everyone's just doing what they can to survive should. Personalities will warp, chances for even a fleeting moment of relief or happiness will be taken, but there still can be even the smallest speck of good in there.  Where LISA really shines through though are it's story and characters. The mood is portrayed really well with a wondeful mix of soundtrack, storytelling, and visuals. Little bits where the game doesn't take itself too seriously are sprinkled about the story, but it's still able to remind you just how bleak the situation is. It's also one of the few games where you don't HAVE to play the prequel, LISA: The First, to enjoy the story. But at the same time doing so will explain a lot of things about the trilogy's namesake character.   Speaking of the prequel, another thing I really adore is how this series touches on sensetive subjects without using them just for shock value. It also doesn't portray said abuse victims as beautifully broken people who can do no wrong because of what they've endured. You can sympathize with the trilogy's three protagonists, yes, but their actions in one game or across many will still make you question the kind of person they really are. As a survivor of abuse myself, the personalities of Brad, Lisa, and Buddy all speak out to me very much. And speaking of people...  The party members and the NPCs! How could I write a review for this game without mentioning these colorful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s? I've only seen a handful of games that offer a variety of recruitable folks to join you that still make them all unique! The game manages to not draw out their time to the point where some would nitpick about it, but still manage to give them some pretty powerful personalities! The NPCs, albeit important to the story or not, are also solid proof about what I said about blurring the lines of morality. Across the trilogy, reoccuring characters aren't written off as inherently good or evil, but as burdened by their various pasts and coping with it in different ways. A character you could hate in one game could redeem themselves in the next, or a character you loved in one game could do something unforgivable in another.  I've heard a few complaints about the world of Olathe, in that it's very linear. And honestly, I'd have to agree. But at the same time it's vast enough for you to discover all sorts of hidden secrets or just fun easter eggs. Linear doesn't necessarily equate to bad, but the variety always helps.  Another I've heard is the ever popular 'it's too hard!'. To which I have to respond: Dude, it's known by its fans as 'LISA: The Painful RPG' and even has a harder difficulty called Pain Mode. If you walked into this game not expecting it to try and kick your ♥♥♥, Then I'll probably assume you're also one of those people who expected Dark Souls to not be hard and not really know what to say to you.   All in all: this game is a masterpiece and well worth the 15 dollars for both the game itself and it's sequel-DLC, LISA: The Joyful. And on top of that? LISA: The First is entirely free. I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a good story with some challenging gameplay!

So, before I begin, I would like to thank Dingaling for providing a fresh and fun entry into the indie genre, one that has affected me and many others greatly, and hopefully will endure the test of time.  I feel that the first thing I should do is address the drawing of parallels between Undertale and LISA. These games may share quite a bit, but it is absolutely NOT worth comparing the two, as they share completely different themes and gameplay focuses. Undertale's focus is more on gathering friendships and the value of those friendships. Undertale likes to be fair(so long as you are going pacifist), and will reward you for playing along. LISA is a take on how everything can be taken away from us in the blink of an eye, even if you DO play along. Choices you make will be difficult, they will have an effect on you in the moment, and will make your journey significantly more difficult, as you cannot avoid these decisions.  It's unfair.   Life is unfair.   I will now break down LISA into pros/cons like the good little reviewer I was born to be.  Pros: -Great soundtrack, I still listen to a few of the songs on my own time, and each area has it's own little (widdly2)diddly as you walk about and absorb the atmosphere.  -Incredible atmosphere, LISA is hopeless, you will feel hopeless, but that's part of the enjoyment, the comedy given to you in the form of characters and wacky situations help raise your spirits to give you the motivation to continue on regardless.  -Story(?), LISA easily has one of the most dark and inhuman storylines of any game I've ever had the pleasure of playing, it will destroy your sense of being and bring you back to the light only to send you back to hell. It makes you feel things. It's good.  -Combat(?), Although many would say combat was the shortcoming of LISA, I actually found it a bit fun, it works on a basic WASD dial combo system to dial in skills for extra damage. If you were too lazy to learn the combos yourself, you could simply circumvent the dial combos and go straight to the skill menu. This feature was a blessing and a curse, the latter I will explain later.  -Art, The art was nothing special to be honest, but it was definitely really good and the earthy tones really helped convey the tone Dingaling was going for.   Now, onto our cons.  -Difficulty Curve, LISA's main selling point may just be it's downfall. It's hard. This game was incredibly hard in it's beginning stages, albeit it becomes easier as the game goes on, it almost turned me off and has actually turned off many other players from continuing the game. Anyone who buys this needs to understand that you'll need to push past that first crossroads before the game picks up and you can actually fight things.  -Combat(?), LISA's combat is a real crapshoot, you either like it or hate it, or who knows, you might be fine with it, but it definitely wasn't anything revolutionary and ESPECIALLY in the beginning stages it's tedious as hell and can really get frustrating to fight anything. It gets better later on, but as I said, the steep curve of this game turns players off right from the beginning without showing them a light at the end of the tunnel  -Story(?), LISA's story is ♥♥♥♥ed up, and for the most people, hardly relateable. It's really dark and depending on your life experiences you will either become enthralled in it's world or be completely turned off by it's harshness. Really a matter of preference.  -♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ING CLIFFS, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T  Overall, I rate LISA:The Painful RPG a 8/10, could have been better on the mechanics side of thing, but overall an amazing title and a great addition to anyone's library.

LISA: The Painful is quite frankly one of the most fun yet devestating rpg maker games I've ever had the JOY of playing. However I honestly believe LISA is a game better played with no plot context, so for that reason I'll leave the plot element at 'This plot has legit made me laugh, cry, and feel just uncomfortable enough to say it was disturbing but never to a point where I wanted to quit playing.' All of this and enough ambiguity to leave some things up to the player themselves and I'm always down for games that let you come up with your own interpretations of certain elements.  Don't get me wrong, this game would no question go on my personal top 10 list of rpgs (or dare I say any games in general) but the experience is what I would call an aquired taste and it really isn't the type of game I'd reccomend to everyone. But if you've been on the edge of wanting this, think it's your kind of game, I'd say it's worth every damn penny.  Reasons you might really like LISA: -The story is one of the best I've seen in recent years -The game in general take inspiration from Earthbound and actually pulls it off really effectively -Terry Hintz -Decisions in a game that actually drastically effect gameplay as opposed to feeling weightless to the overall experience -A fish lawyer on legs -The difficulty never goes into the 'Impossible' territory, It's always pretty much in the 'hard but fair' range. -30+ Party members for a lot of combination potential  Reasons you might NOT like LISA: -The game works off a high amount of dark humor, which works well for the setting but isnt really everyone's cup of tea -Laaaaaarge amounts of gore/body horror, again, not everyone's jam -Family abuse is a really heavy and prominant theme of the game -Mandatory Russian Roulette (with permadeath) -The ability to savescum might make some of the game's choices a little less impactful, but that's more of a personal play preference thing. -You'll cry -A lot -No I'm serious you're gonna cry I promise.

Instead of revealing Buddy to Rando and his army, Brad decides to hide her along with his three childhood friends Rick, Cheeks, and Sticky. The years past by and Buddy is now a older child but not yet a teenager, but then Brad fast forwards to him being drunk and high in the middle of nowhere. This is probably mostly just opinion but bear with me.  Overall I personally don't recommend LISA. Even as a fan of the Mother series and it's successors The charm doesn't seem to be there. I see much of it as flawed. Execution fallen flat. Many may like it but I feel people shouldn't play simply because of all the hype. IMO Be wary.  The gameplay is my biggest gripe. It doesn't feel new. Yes it's just like Earthbound but still there isn't as much polish. Shoving a metric butt ton of party characters does not an interesting rpg make. Obviously you're just gonna pick the best ones and leave the others sitting around like imperfectly bred pokes in the pc. There isn't much strategy to picking who to use it's more of who can do the most damage and/or heal the most. A good RPG gives you a handful of characters and tells you to make due.  I know why they gave so many characters and it's because it has to compensate for the 'pain' Which is just another way of saying how many ways you can be screwed over by RNGeesus. Perma death is a thing and it can happen on a whim. Not like Fire Emblem/XCom/Valkyria Chronicles where you made a fatal error. It's because that's just how the dice rolled. The enemy did an insta-kill move you didn't dodge or resist and that's that. It isn't common and you may not have had it happen to you but it's there. If there's anything I know is that for me that one percent of failure is a very real threat with my luck. But simply put It's more like getting annihilated by critical hits in a Nuzlocke run.  Then there's Joy addiction. Oh boy what fun it is to sit through a withdrawal. Every 300 frames/5 minutes that you don't transition between areas the game flips a coin. This determines if any of your Joy addled party members go into total noodle arm mode. Pretty much reducing any physical attacks they do into someone throwing cotton balls. You don't get over it through time though. It's either by resting (a risk depending on where you sleep) or going through 20-30 turns in battle. It takes a mildy interesting idea of dealing with addiction through gameplay and turns it into a major inconvenience. Especially since you can work around it with special attacks. I've had withdrawals from medication and I can tell you it sucks. But the way the game handles it doesn't drive it home. If it had actual symptoms of withdrawal like wooziness (occasionally miss) weakness (halved damage) or nausea (sp drain) as simple examples then I'd be ok with it. However as it is, this is less like heroine addiction and more like having a ♥♥♥♥ drunk friend that you have to take care of. Yes I know the world is supposed to be 'unfair' and that it was done this way to hammer that fact in but It's just lazy. I could go on for millenia about this but in short it's just fake difficulty.  Another aspect about having so many party members is the choice to save one's life. The game storepage seems somewhat proud of that. I personally haven't done chosen against it because I am a goodie two shoes but at the same time I think that it would just be easier to plan accordingly so I can send off a weakling. Because I've looked into it and there are no ill effects whatsoever. Most of the characters have little personality beyond their character design so one wouldn't feel torn about losing someone. This isn't like Mass Effect where a choice between Ashley or Kaiden must be made (although I've never liked either character) But these are people you can learn to care for. Sacrifice is hollow here.  The story is definitely slow. I do appreciate that it fills itself in through bits and pieces but the more it does it seems too simple and shallow. It is rather cliched imo. Especially in Brad. He's got the best intentions but is much like his father. Classic apple and tree scenario. The abusive father thing is also there. What annoys me is that the father seems to just be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ just to fill the role. Right in the beginning it felt like he just had to hurt him. His reasoning barely held up. Having read up on the backstory his actions simply don't make sense. There major are lulls in the story as well where basically it's just dealing with whatever shows up. And whenever anything does happen it just feels like it's trying to be total grimdark. I assume the pacing is meant to keep the player from burning out however instead I started to dread the possibility of the next story event. Another problem is that some of the character interactions frustrate me. Although that's probably my personal gripe with a lot of tragedy stories shining through. In tragedies character flaws will always explode even in the most level headed man for no apparent reason other than to produce a negative outcome. I tend to sit on the cold logical side so it's always a pain to me. Oh well not everything can be Hamlet.   In regards to the humor it's kinda hit or miss for me. I started to just turn off later on because I simply stopped caring for the jokes so I couldn't even give them a fair shake. I just wanted to get through the dialogue. Don't get me wrong I love dark humor, I have the entirety of Johnny the Homicidal Maniac (which I would recommend for fans of this game.) sitting on my bookcase but this stuff just couldn't jibe with me. Maybe it was too predictable maybe it was just that the tone didn't quite match. I just can't put my finger on it.  If there's something good I could say it's that the music can be pretty kickass at times.  Put simply I say meh to this even in all my negativity. Pessimism HOOO!~ Although it's a meh that means that I'll probably never pick it back up to finish.

LISA the Overrated  I might be learning disabled because I can't seem to derive meaning from a lifelong pattern of being disappointed by games that were overwhelmingly praised for their story. On the other hand, it occurs to me that it's this vocal majority that suffers from a learning disability because they don't understand what 'story' means. The story is the sequence of actions and events that propels a narrative forward. Of the 5 hours I played, only the first 10 minutes contained any story. The other 4 hours and 50 minutes was a loop of 'grind for EXP -> boss -> darn, ya just missed your daughter'.  Often, people mistakenly say 'story' when they mean 'characters' or 'atmosphere'. Even so, the characters of LISA are absurd caricatures slapped onto disposable damage sponges. They're not charming, deep or endearing. They're just there to even the odds against your enemies. As for atmosphere...there are the makings of it sprinkled throughout the game...but the disparate elements never converge into a cohesive or coherent whole. You can see the vision the creator had, but the game, unfortunately, fails to manifest it completely. Everything ends up feeling like a cheap parody instead of a genuine post-apocalypse.  Of course, the failing of the story (or perhaps its pacing) might be overlooked if the aforementioned 4 hours and 50 minutes were spent enjoyably. And if I was the sort of man who enjoyed mental/emotional grinds, I suppose they would've been. But I'm not...and they weren't. I will proceed to catalog in detail why that time was not fun:  The combat is pointlessly shallow, rivaling rock-paper-scissors at the height of its strategic apex. If your party isn't composed of the worst characters and you're not dangerously under-leveled, combat consists of pressing Enter until it's over.  The oft touted 'dramatic/meaningful choices' chalk up to mild inconveniences for the most part. My personal favorites: 'Lose a party member or sacrifice easily obtained items from your inventory' and 'A party member has been kidnapped so now you must backtrack for 5 minutes to retrieve him without so much as a confrontation with the guilty party'.  The equally oft touted 'dark humor' is...there...in some disjointed fashion. There are dark bits that are clearly trying to be funny but aren't. And then there are ridiculous one liners at the end of battles that will either tickle your taint or not. Some of those one liners were surprisingly good.  The music consists of 2 tracks that are pleasant, catchy and original and 3 or 4 additional tracks that are generic and grating. The rest is just ambient noise. However, I can see why the 2 enjoyable tracks would have people raving about the soundtrack. It's a classic case of surpassing a void of expectation. And that about sums up this game and its overwhelmingly positive rating.  The idea of LISA and its Mad Max-ian, deranged-mutant-freakshow-of-a-world is a delightfully refreshing and singular take on the seemingly-beaten-to-death setting of civil collapse. But executing that idea as a parody with generic JRPG mechanics in GameMaker (of all things) was, I think, a mistake. One that lead to disappointment, dissatisfaction, and dullness in the wake of expected refreshment.

LISA is a post-apocalyptic turn-based RPG with an 8-bit grindhouse aesthetic. Like any grindhouse movie, the violence, swearing, and uncomfortable sexual overtones that the game forces on you are gratuitous and handled without an ounce of nuance or subtlety.   Lets get the gameplay out of the way first. Bog-standard RPG combat with a pointless combo system that is incredibly tedious to play once you understand how it works (never explained, btw). Find the best combo and spam it. Go back and forth between big, empty levels where you do little more than climb up and down platforms for seemingly no reason than to extend the playtime of the game.   Completely lifeless level design through and through. After the 'shock' of seeing mutilated bodies and blood splatters wears off (clock that at about 3 seconds) you'll find that you're just pressing on from screen to screen without really taking in any scenery...because there isn't any. It's just big brown screens with platforms and ropes, forever.  LISA prides itself on being challenging and forcing you to make hard choices with its 'make a sacrifice or lose a party member' mechanic and the fact that resting in many spots will often incur a large penalty onto your party. These are the only cool things about the game, and I will give points for these interesting mechanics! That said, any 'difficulty' in a turn-based RPG is always nullified by grinding, which LISA encourages you to do, relentlessly, with a propensity to throw you into an inescapable combat at a moment's notice - hope you're levelled up enough, or saved recently.  Back to the elephant in the room, though - the art direction/tone of the game. I'm sure there are people out there who play games like this and go, '♥♥♥♥ yeah! Finally, some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s make a real game that isn't afraid to show you some ♥♥♥♥ed-up ♥♥♥♥ like a guy's head getting bashed in with a baseball bat and jokes about ♥♥♥♥♥♥ a little girl!' LISA caters explicitly to this demographic, and naturally comes with the token pretense of intellectualism. You know, the 'ooh, this is humanity when society breaks down, man' ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that makes people think they're experiencing something other than pure, animalistic carnage for the sake of carnage.  It's not that I'm even against that, in the right hands. You know who did this better? Hotline Miami. The aesthetic, the mood, the Heart of Darkness horror, all of it done loads better, in a game that was actually fun to play. If you want to drill into an NES sprite's skull, you can do that in both games - but Hotline Miami is a game first, and a snuff film second.  This is not a good game, and I'm devoting more words to it than it deserves. Don't buy it, don't play it.

The tagline of this game couldn't be more accurate. LISA: The Painful RPG isn't afraid to delve into territories most consumers will likely be turned off by: childhood sexual abuse, drug addiction, lots of violence. The journey of the main character, Brad, is a downward spiral into a world of pessimistic nihilism, where the motto 'Anything that can go wrong, will go wrong' is an inescapable reality.   The story:   We're introduced to Brad Armstrong at a very young age; us waiting very little time before witnessing his abusive relationship with his father; the neglectful state of the home he lives in; and, of course, his little sister, Lisa.   Cut to many years later, soon after an unexplained event that killed off the female population -- the world has been driven into a sort of Fallout/Borderlands/Mad Max state of chaos, where societies have broken down into roaming, violent gangs. This is the last age of humanity, as there is no way to reproduce, and very little hope for the world remains.  That is, until, Brad -- now aged and addicted to a drug called 'joy' -- stumbles upon a baby in the middle of nowhere... A baby girl.   And without knowing how she got there, or why, he takes it upon himself to raise her as his own, vowing to keep her identity a secret from the world, for fear that if she was ever discovered, she would be subjected to the same abuse he and his little sister were subjected to as children.   However, despite his careful attempts to conceal her gender, she is one day discovered and kidnapped. And so Brad vows to undergo a dangerous journey to save her from a fate worse than death.   ...  LISA is not a happy game, despite the plentiful amount of Borderlands/Fallout-style post-apocalyptic humor thrown in. It is a game not only about sacrificing parts of Brad's body, but also his humanity; what little remains that makes him a good person -- all for a small, slim hope.   I have to say, the last thirty or so minutes of the game were so gutwrenching and expertly handled, I had to stop and just think for like ten minutes after the credits began to roll. Seriously, it was masterful.   Gameplay:  LISA plays very much like a side-scrolling Earthbound, with unlockable attacks, different party members and first-person-style turned-based combat. It's pretty fun, and provides a pretty decent challenge -- although sometimes the difficulty can spike when you least expect it, providing sort of an uneven curve. Not a huge deal though.  The primary complaints I have are with the interface, especially when trying to use the shops. For some reason, whenever I am looking at weapons I potentially want to buy, I am unable to compare them to anyone else but my immediate party. Which means I have to leave the shop, run over to a gang sign, switch my party out, and then go back to the shop. It's strange because this isn't an issue when I'm buying from an armor shop. In addition, many pieces of equipment will affect multiple stats (like agility, luck, etc), but, when comparing your equipment in the shops, I am only able to see the attack comparison for weapons, and the defense comparison for armor. So there are times when I have spent a ton of mags on an 'upgrade' when the item is actually a downgrade, simply because I was unable to see all of the stat changes prior to my purchase. I guess it's possible that I'm an idiot and am doing something horribly wrong, but, after almost 30 hours of playing, I'm decently confident that I've tried everything.  Overall, despite some of those aforementioned, minor complaints, LISA is a fantastic and criminally underrated game.   Oh, and the music is freaking awesome, too.   So go play it!    Final Verdict:  A solid 9/10.

Alternative Names: Depression: The RPG.  Is that an original joke? Ah I don't care.  LISA: The Painful is a great game about sacrifice, and does a pretty good joke showing how that sacrifice is perceived from both sides. It starts off with a fairly dark premise, of child abuse, selfish redemption, the end of the world, and some guy willingly letting their child put makeup on them. Initially the darkness is well balanced out by the game's humor, which is simply superb.  People say Undertale was Earthbound inspired, but this game BREATHES Earthbound far more than Undertale could ever hope. From the art style, to the combat system, to quite a bit of the humor, this is a game that Earthbound fans would appreciate. Only a game like this could have an utterly soul crushing moment of character development, and then have a joke where a blind bandit attempts to ambush you and utterly misses.   The Sacrifice system is pretty interesting as well, and most of the characters do a decent job of making those moments when the choices happen all the more impactful.  It's a game that does a perfect job of balancing humor, and throwing your soul into a juicy meat grinder. One that's put on the slowest setting. And then they switch it off near the end to let you suffer.  It has some flaws, but most of them are pretty much obscured by the positives, sans maybe one or two.  9/10. Buy it if you really want to laugh, feel bad, laugh again, and then feel horrible about that laughing.   Oh, and that DLC? LISA: The Joyful?  It's hard to describe it without spoilering anything, so I won't. It perfectly continues the story however. But uh, except a harder soul crushing by the end. The game just switchs that grinder to an even more agonizingly slow setting.
